Yes, the authorities at the Shrine face environmental and climate challenges, as the region experiences hot and arid conditions. The temperature during the Hajj pilgrimage can go up to 40 to 50 degrees Celsius, and it can be challenging for pilgrims to undertake religious practices in such high temperatures. The heat can cause heat strokes, dehydration, and other health issues, especially for the elderly and those with medical conditions.

Moreover, the arid climate of the region can lead to water scarcity, and managing the water supply becomes critical during the pilgrimage. The authorities have devised a complex system of water transportation and distribution to ensure the availability of clean water for the pilgrims.

Another environmental challenge faced by the Shrine is waste management. With millions of pilgrims visiting the site during the Hajj, the production of waste becomes inevitable. The authorities have developed a comprehensive waste management system to collect, sort, and dispose of the waste efficiently and sustainably.

Overall, the authorities face several environmental and climate challenges in managing the Shrine. Still, they have implemented innovative solutions and technologies to ensure that these challenges do not hinder the pilgrims' spiritual experience while also preserving the environment.
